newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian Metals-Indonesia buying aluminium, China out.
newsitem.headline: Asian Metals-Indonesia buying aluminium, China out.

text.p: Indonesian aluminium purchases have risen sharply recently while Chinese copper buyers are waiting on the sidelines for a dip in current high copper prices on the London Metal Exchange (LME), traders said on Friday.

"Indonesian buying of aluminium is running at a good pace," an aluminium dealer for a Singapore-based commodity house said, adding the purchases had picked-up steam after companies found their stocks were running low.
One major Indonesian company recently bought up to 5,000 tonnes of aluminium in the last two weeks.
"They never anticipated they would need that much aluminium," a trader said. "They're buying now to rebuild their stocks of the metal."

"In the short-term, their demand for aluminium has firmed. The Indonesians did not enter into many long-term contracts because they thought premiums would come down. Some of them found themselves a bit short as a result," a dealer for a major European metal trading company added.
Premiums of western grade 20-25 kg aluminium ingots have climbed in the past month by U$5-$10 to $90-$95 a tonne CIF Jakarta, Singapore dealers said.
Aluminium premiums in Singapore were seen at around $65-$83 a tonne, they said.
Aluminium demand in Taiwan remains steady while the trade was divided about the level of activity in Japan.
"It's very quiet now in Japan," an aluminium dealer for a Japanese trading house said. "There's not much spot business going on."

But another European trader said reports that aluminium demand in Japan had died down were deceptive since premiums for the second quarter remain buoyant at around the mid-$80 a tonne level over cash LME prices.
"The premiums would not be that firm if demand is not there," the trader said.
China was also seen engaged in small-lot aluminium buying, but was not much of a factor in the market.
The Chinese have also shied away from the copper market and are waiting for a correction in LME prices before going in, dealers said.

"The Chinese are not buying," Vinod Kumar, managing director of Singapore metal company Donald Mcarthy, said, adding his firm recently held discussions with potential buyers in China. "Nobody seems interested in these prices."
Kumar said Chinese interest in copper will only perk up once prices fall below $2,400 a tonne.
A trader for a Japanese metal dealing company said the Chinese will stay out of the market unless prices come off.
"It does not make sense for them to come in at this level," the dealer said.
Three-month copper prices were quoted by regional traders at around $2,400/05 a tonne at 0330 GMT, a shade firmer from the late LME quote on Thursday of $2,398/402 a tonne.
Spot business for the other base metals in the region remained stagnant, dealers said.
Kumar said business has slowed down "to a trickle. It's not exciting."
"There's nothing spectacular going on," a dealer for a European metal house said. "We heard a few inquiries and I imagine they're from China. But it's pretty much stagnant."
Singapore metal dealers said prices in the LME will be looking to the stocks report due out at 0900 GMT on Friday for leads in the market.
Traders here expect copper inventories to decline between 2,000-5,000 tonnes while aluminium stocks are seen falling by about 5,000-10,000 tonnes.
A fall in aluminium stocks may spur three-month metal for a fresh try at the $1,700 level after a kerb close on the LME yesterday of $1,689 a tonne.
"It will try for $1,700 again," a Japanese trader said.
Singapore indications as a premium to LME cash prices (Warrant/premiums):
March 7 Feb 28
Aluminium - Western (20-25 kg ingots) +65-83 +70-85
Aluminium - Indian (20-25 kg ingots) +45-60 +55
Aluminium - Russian (20-25 kg ingots) +45-60 +55
Aluminium - Indonesian (20-25 kg ingots) +65-80 +70-80
Copper - Grade A cathodes, 99.9 pct +25-35 +20-30
Zinc - 25 kg ingots/99.9 pct +20-25 +20-25
-- Singapore Newsroom (65-8703305)
